the process of when they do the slaughtering you've got to do certain checks. You've got to check the
no blemishes on the lungs as an instance. So I watched as they slaughtered these two cows.
Another aside, a little smaller side, this Rabbi Smith who I just mentioned was a shokhtim, was an
old gentleman and he the shokhtim, my father in charge at the time, the slaughtermen said at one
point refused to work with him and they said Rabbi Smith I'm very sorry you're too old. We don't
trust you anymore. You're going to do damage. So he said to them that's fine. He said will you work
with me if we have a competition and I win? And they said what type of competition? So he said if
we have a push-up competition and I win, he said that you bring your fittest man and I will do
push-ups on the floor against him now. If I win, I stay on. If he wins, I will leave immediately.
Rabbi Smith was working the next day. He used to walk regularly from Stanford Hill to Golders Green.
He was a very fit gentleman. He might not have looked fit but he was. I also remember being in
the Rabbi's house talking about shkita when in order to do shkita you have to use what they call
a chalif which is a special ritual knife. That knife is going to be razor razor sharp and have
no indentations. You check that by running it against your thumbnail. Again the Rabbi was an
old dodgery as I would say. I had all respect for him. He wasn't dodgery but that's the way I describe
him and he then ran his back of his nail against this knife to check it was kosher and it was there.
